item.title: Roman Storm’s Defense Team Accuses U.S. Government Of Withholding Key Exculpatory Evidence
item.description:
Roman Storm’s legal team has asserted that federal prosecutors possessed exculpatory FinCEN communications since August 2023 that clarify Tornado Cash’s non-custodial design, challenging the government’s portrayal of the mixer as a money transmitter months before the scheduled trial.

The post Roman Storm’s Defense Team Accuses U.S. Government Of Withholding Key Exculpatory Evidence appeared first on Cryptonews.

item.title: Procolored Printer Drivers Slip Bitcoin-Stealing Trojan, Draining $950K from Users
item.description:
Procolored has distributed infected printer drivers for at least six months, embedding XRedRAT remote-access malware and SnipVex Bitcoin clipboard hijacker. The breach has stolen 9.3 BTC and forced the parent firm to replace all downloads after May 8 2025.

The post Procolored Printer Drivers Slip Bitcoin-Stealing Trojan, Draining $950K from Users appeared first on Cryptonews.

item.title: Circle’s $5B Showdown: Will Coinbase Outbid Ripple After Rejected Offer?
item.description:
Circle has been weighing parallel options: a public listing valued near $5 billion and confidential talks to sell itself for roughly the same price to either Coinbase or Ripple. The discussions have spotlighted USDC’s strategic importance and each bidder’s recent deal-making capacity.

The post Circle’s $5B Showdown: Will Coinbase Outbid Ripple After Rejected Offer? appeared first on Cryptonews.

item.title: Dough Finance Hack: $2.5M Lost – Will Silent World Liberty Partners Repay Investors?
item.description:
Dough Finance has been grappling with fallout from a July 2024 exploit that siphoned $2.5 million from investor Jonathan Lopez. Co-founders Chase Herro and Zachary Folkman have pledged to make users whole, but progress has stalled and Lopez’s lawsuit heads to trial in April 2026.

The post Dough Finance Hack: $2.5M Lost – Will Silent World Liberty Partners Repay Investors? appeared first on Cryptonews.

item.title: SEC’s Peirce States Many NFTs Don’t Qualify as Securities, Including Creator-Compensating Tokens
